title: Who will be elected governor of Virginia in November 2017?
possible_answers: Ralph Northam (Democrat) by a margin greater than 5%
Ralph Northam (Democrat) by a margin of 5% or less
Ed Gillespie (Republican) by a margin of 5% or less
Ed Gillespie (Republican) by a margin greater than 5%
correct_answer: Ralph Northam (Democrat) by a margin greater than 5%
preds: Hat tip to those who had the confidence to stick with the >5% Northam bin.
CNN just called for Northam. Now, it's just a question of whether the margin will exceed 5%.
Up by 3 right now with N Va later in counting. So adjusting the more than 5 bucket.

Increasing my forecast for a Northam win based on 8pm Eastern vote counts: Gillespie counties have turnout at or below expected levels; Northam counties (northern VA and Richmond area) have strong turnout and (so far) stronger margins than McAuliffe recorded in the last gubernatorial race. Demographics favor Northam.

l report a lead for Northam, only one poll among the five conducted by Quinnipiac University indicates that Northam's lead is outside the margin of error. The size of Northam’s lead ranges from 9 percent in the Quinnipiac poll to a 1 percent lead in a Polling Company result. The average lead reported for Northam across the five polls is 4 percent. With the exception of the Quinnipiac poll, which began surveying voters on Oct. 29, the polls released today did not begin surveying voters until Nov. 2. However, a Monmouth University poll released on Oct. 17 indicating a 1 percent lead for Gillespie—the first result since March to suggest a lead for the Republican—suggested that the race had potentially tightened. This was followed by three additional polls pointing to a Gillespie lead and a Rasmussen poll indicating a tied race. Since Oct. 17, a total of 18 polls have been released. Of those, 13 have reported a lead for Northam, while four have shown Gillespie in the lead, and one has indicated that the candidates are tied. Of the 13 polls to report a lead for Northam, three have shown him leading outside the margin of error.

From CNN on November 7th, 2017: "But given the disastrously bad closing week of the race for Northam, the fact he is still ahead at all is somewhat remarkable -- and may speak to the durability of his advantage."
Awfully close in the polls. I think the fundamentals favor Northam. But Gillespie has a real—albeit outside, in my opinion—chance.
Last batch of polls today looks like it’s all Northam (barely).

The race continues to tighten, and voter turnout is by far the key. See https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/monkey-cage/wp/2017/11/06/how-polling-methodology-affects-ralph-northams-lead-in-the-virginia-governors-race/ for a good explanation of how much the weighting of "likely" voters affects polling results. Probabilities in the Northam by >5% margin bin are wasted, IMHO, especially given that the ordered scoring rule gives partial credit for probabilities in adjacent bins. And, if Gillespie wins by >5%, it will be a massive black-eye for virtually all polling and other analyses to date. So, the only question is how to split the probabilities in the other two buckets. I've gone with 70/30, favoring a Northam win for the simple reasons that (1) in 2016, Virginia went for Clinton, and shows no sign of becoming "redder" demographically, and (2) with almost no exceptions, polls of likely voters have shown Northam as winning. But, the Dems are perfectly capable of blowing this race, which was and remains theirs to lose.

polling released today by	Hampton 
	Northam 33, Gillespie 41

A Monmouth University poll of the Virginia gubernatorial election released yesterday is the first since March to show former Republican National Committee Chairman Ed Gillespie (R) leading Lt. Gov. Ralph Northam (D). The poll of 408 likely voters found that 48 percent planned on voting for Gillespie, while 47 percent planned on voting for Northam. The poll is one of three to be released Tuesday; a weekly Christopher Newport tracking survey found Northam ahead of Gillespie by four percent (48-44), a three percent decrease from the previous week's 49-42 lead reported for Northam. Meanwhile, a Roanoke College poll found Northam leading Gillespie 50-44.

Holding fast at 75/25 Northam/Gillespie, with only a small chance (5%) of Northam >5% margin. My overall split is comparable to the current PredictIt consensus (78/22, advantage Northam): https://www.predictit.org/Market/2404/Which-party-will-win-the-2017-Virginia-gubernatorial-race The most recent polls gathered by RealClearPolitics are split badly, although Monmouth's slight edge for Gillespie is the first such result in quite a while. Early turnout data from the US Elections Project (http://www.electproject.org/home) fall into the "too early to draw conclusions" category. Will need to revisit soon, perhaps to see if Obama's campaign appearance tonight energizes VA voters.

It's coming down to voter turnout now. Northam has led or tied in every poll since July, and two of the September polls put his margin at more than 5%. But, even though the most recent Wason Center poll gives Northam a 6% margin (albeit with a 3.7% margin of error at the 95% confidence level), their assistant director sounded a cautionary note in characterizing the results: "'The Democratic field clearly has an advantage now,' said Rachel Bitecofer, assistant director of the Wason Center. 'The question is whether they can turn out their voters on Election Day, something the party traditionally struggles with in off-year elections.'” (http://wasoncenter.cnu.edu/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/Sept-25-Report-Final.pdf) I've nudged up my Northam >5% forecast, with a corresponding decrease in my Gillespie 5% or less forecast on the latest polling numbers.

Popularity of a party a year after winning a presidential election is bound to fall, especially given that Trump is the president, but Right wing tend to be less vocal in polls (and clearly more likely to vote Republican than popularity figures would suggest) and turn out in greater numbers in state elections. This balances out to give Republicans a slight edge above their performance as forecasted by the polls.

September polls are all over the place, from a tie (Suffolk) to a less than 5% Northam victory (Mason-Dixon and FOX News) to a greater than 10% Northam victory (Quinnipiac). https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2017/governor/va/virginia_governor_gillespie_vs_northam-6197.html#polls Treating Quinnipiac as an outlier - which has been true all along, I give heavy weight to the central tendency for a Northam victory with a less than 5% margin. But, with margins of error in the 4% range or greater, both adjacent possibilities (Northam greater than 5% and Gillespie less than 5%) are plausible outcomes. The possibility of systematically correlated polling errors makes me most uncomfortable in the direction of a Gillespie victory, so I'm giving that bin a substantially higher weight than the Northam greater than 5% bin. Fortunately, the "ordered scoring rule" for this question gives partial credit for near-misses, so I feel comfortable hedging my bets this way. I see little value, though, in putting any eggs in the Gillespie more than 5% basket. I'll be watching for indications of the # of absentee voters from different parts of the state and will adjust my forecast based on that as well as updated polling numbers.

ADVANTAGE DEMOCRATS. Not by force effort mind you. but rather by default as establishment Republicans continue to take the wind out of conservative hopes.
In 2017, the first state legislative seat to switch from Democrat to Republican as a result of a special election was the District 42 seat of the Louisiana House of Representatives. The first state legislative seat to switch from Republican to Democrat as a result of a special election was Carroll 6 of the New Hampshire House of Representatives. Democrats flipped another Republican seat in District 9 of the New York State Assembly District 9. On July 11, Democratic candidates in Oklahoma won election to Senate District 44 and House District 75, flipping those seats from Republican control to Democratic control. On September 12, Democrats flipped the Belknap 9 district in the New Hampshire House of Representatives. Democrats flipped a second seat on September 12 in District 46 of the Oklahoma House of Representatives.

This forecast represents a composite of several different ways of looking at the election. In brief, I think both candidates have a hardcore base that would vote for them regardless of any normal developments that may occur between now and election day. I think that hardcore base is slightly smaller for Northam than for Gillespie. However, I think Northam benefits from Trump's politics, which will energize his base and dampen Gillespie's base. Among swing voters, I think Northam benefits from being more well-known than Gillespie, and benefits from being associated with the outgoing Terry McAulliffe, and therefore appeals to voters that want to preserve the status quo.

No new polls since my last forecast, but upon careful consideration, I've shifted my Northam forecast more heavily to a 5% or less margin. Unless I see a significant uptick in Northam's polling margins, I'm going to stick with the sense that this is a very tight race.

VA leans Democrat.  And Northram has the credentials to appeal to that side of what will be a partisan contest.  However, Trump's sway with the overall electorate means that Gillespie cannot be counted out of the fight.

Polls are showing Northam with roughly 7% lead at the moment. Still lots of time on the clock for the unforeseeable to occur, but at this stage it looks highly likely Northam wins, the recent miscues of polls notwithstanding.

Democrats have been doing well in gubernatorial races in Virginia recently, but Gillespie has shown his ability to make a tight race out of expected landslides, like his race against Warner in 2014. Virginia also has a history of voting against the party controlling the White House, with McCaulliffe being the first exception in decades.
The urban areas have been and continue with a demographic change related to DC employment that I believe will depress turnout and favor Gellespie.

I think Northam has a clear advantage in both polling and recent history. Going back to 2001 democrats have won three times and republicans have won once. He also have a small but consistent lead on the polls (see link) so I think we see Virginia's democratic swing continue this year. DC suburbs are wildly anti-Trump, likely strongly motivated to turn out.  Polling has not been frequent thus far and it indicates a dead heat, which leads me to be cautious regarding Northam margin.  But between Trump scandals heating up around that time and the fallout from Charlottesville, I would think Northam supporters would be highly motivated to put him over the top.

Looking at the nice polling summary on Wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virginia_gubernatorial_election,_2017), it seems Northam has in general maintained a lead on Gillespie.  Other factors to consider: 
Gillespie has been increasingly embracing Trump (https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/gillespie-shifts-from-avoiding-trump-to-dropping-the-presidents-name/2017/07/20/d3bab1e2-6d68-11e7-96ab-5f38140b38cc_story.html), which, after this weekend, may be more of a detriment than a boon. After all, his statement after the incident was tepid at best (https://edforvirginia.com/2017/08/12/gillespie-statement-events-charlottesville/), and failed to condemn white supremacy movements or reiterate his support for maintaining Confederate monuments (in short, failing to take a stand one way or the other). Looking at the 2013 election results (http://www.politico.com/2013-election/results/governor/virginia/), I think it's likely Northam will win Northern VA (DC suburbs), Southeastern VA (Norfolk area), and Richmond, which are the largest population centers in the state. For Gillespie to have a chance, he needs those areas to be close, winning at least one of the NOVA or Norfolk area counties, while significantly running up the margins in the more rural counties. I think it will likely be Northam, and likely by less than 5%, given previous results.
Trump seems likely to do continue actions that make republicans unacceptable to in increasing number of voters.

Virginia is considered a new swing state: historically it has voted Republican in presidential elections, but has voted Democrat since 2008. In fact, in 2016 the Republican presidential candidate received a fewer % of votes than any other Republican presidential candidate in over 50 years. This indicates a general shift towards Democrat in the state.  However, comparing presidential election results to governor election results at similar times reveals that there is a lack of correlation between the party that Virginia votes for in presidential elections and the party affiliation of their choice of Governor. Thus, other factors besides party affiliation appear more important to the electorate of Virginia in voting for their Governor. One factor that often impacts a candidate's success is whether they are local to the area. Although more Governors of Virginia have been from somewhere in Virginia, the most recent Governors have not been. So, whilst Ralph Northam's connections to Virginia are unlikely to harm his chances, it is also unlikely that it will win him the election.  Nonetheless, I believe that Ralph Northam is more likely to be elected Governor of Virginia for the following reasons: 1. He has already held positions in Virginia: the people of Virginia have already voted for him multiple times (most recently in 2014), so he clearly has backing in the area. This also means that him and his campaign team have experience and knowledge of campaigning in Virginia - no doubt useful. He has achieved over 55% of the vote in the past, but evidence that the USA has become more partisan makes this less likely.
2. The recent events in Charlottesville will undoubtedly affect the election. The way each candidate responds will alienate at least some voters. By condemning white supremacy, Ralph Northam will only alienate those voters who would never vote Democrat anyway. On the other hand, Ed Gillespie can either choose to condemn white supremacy (which will alienate a section of the core Republican vote), or choose to not condemn white supremacy (which will alienate potential swing voters of a moderate political persuasion). 
3. The general trend towards Democrat in the area combined with very low approval ratings of Donald Trump makes being affiliated with the Republicans electorally inhibiting.
4. Ralph Northam is the type of Democrat likely to appeal to typically Republican voters. He was in the army and is quite fiscally conservative.

Early days yet, but easy to rule out "None of the above." Now, for the rest of the spread: RealClearPolitics polling summary (https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2017/governor/va/virginia_governor_gillespie_vs_northam-6197.html) shows Northam leading in most polls, but only a WaPo poll from May has a statistically significant lead for Northam. Huge national $$ rolling in for both leading candidates (https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/national-money-pours-into-virginia-governors-race/2017/07/25/7e6df1a0-7154-11e7-8839-ec48ec4cae25_story.html), with Gillespie having the financial edge. Unless the polls start to contradict this conclusion, I'm giving Northam the edge on a recent base-rate argument: elected Democrats dominate in Virginia, and Virginians seem to be happy with the way the Dems are handling the state (https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/right-turn/wp/2017/08/10/the-gops-uphill-climb-in-virginia-foreshadows-challenges-elsewhere/). Plus, Gillespie is a traditional Republican politician who had a tough primary challenge from a Trump-supporting iconoclast. Still, I have doubts about Northam's ability to win by greater than 5%. A race to watch closely.
